1.text: As snow in summer, and rain in harvest, so glory is not seemly for a fool.

2.text: As a bird flying to other places, and a sparrow going here or there: so a curse uttered without cause shall come upon a man.

3.text: A whip for a horse, and a snaffle for an ass, and a rod for the back of fools.

4.text: Answer not a fool according to his folly, lest thou be made like him.

5.text: Answer a fool according to his folly, lest he imagine himself to be wise.

6.text: He that sendeth words by a foolish messenger, is lame of feet and drinketh iniquity.

7.text: As a lame man hath fair legs in vain: so a parable is unseemly in the mouth of fools.

8.text: As he that casteth a stone into the heap of Mercury: so is he that giveth honour to a fool.

9.text: As if a thorn should grow in the hand of a drunkard: so is a parable in the mouth of fools.

10.text: Judgment determineth causes: and he that putteth a fool to silence, appeaseth anger.

11.text: As a dog that returneth to his vomit, so is the fool that repeateth his folly.

12.text: Hast thou seen a man wise in his own conceit? there shall be more hope of a fool than of him.

13.text: The slothful man saith: There is a lion in the way, and a lioness in the roads.

14.text: As the door turneth upon its hinges, so doth the slothful upon his bed.

15.text: The slothful hideth his hand under his armpit, and it grieveth him to turn it to his mouth.

16.text: The sluggard is wiser in his own conceit, than seven men that speak sentences.

17.text: As he that taketh a dog by the ears, so is he that passeth by in anger, and meddleth with another manâ€™s quarrel.

18.text: As he is guilty that shooteth arrows, and lances unto death :

19.text: So is the man that hurteth his friend deceitfully: and when he is taken, saith: I did it in jest.

20.text: When the wood faileth, the fire shall go out: and when the talebearer is taken away, contentions shall cease.

21.text: As coals are to burning coals, and wood to fire, so an angry man stirreth up strife.

22.text: The words of a talebearer are as it were simple, but they reach to the innermost parts of the belly.

23.text: Swelling lips joined with a corrupt heart, are like an earthen vessel adorned with silver dross.

24.text: An enemy is known by his lips, when in his heart he entertaineth deceit.

25.text: When he shall speak low, trust him not: because there are seven mischiefs in his heart.

26.text: He that covereth hatred deceitfully, his malice shall be laid open in the public assembly.

27.text: He that diggeth a pit, shall fall into it: and he that rolleth a stone, it shall return to him.

28.text: A deceitful tongue loveth not truth: and a slippery mouth worketh ruin.
